paragraphs.text:
%md
# About This Lab
**Objective:** In this exercise, you will practice working with HDFS—the Hadoop Distributed File System—using the HDFS command line interface. The purpose 
is gain proficiency in loading data into HDFS.
**File locations:** 
    Exercise directory: /home/training/training_material/devsh/exercises/hdfs
    Data files: /home/training/training_material/devsh/data/activations
**Successful outcome:**
**Before you begin:**
**Related lessons:** Explore HDFS Using the Command Line Interface

---

msg.data:
About This Lab

Objective: In this exercise, you will practice working with HDFS—the Hadoop Distributed File System—using the HDFS command line interface. The purpose
is gain proficiency in loading data into HDFS.
File locations:

Exercise directory: /home/training/training_material/devsh/exercises/hdfs
Data files: /home/training/training_material/devsh/data/activations

Successful outcome:
Before you begin:
Related lessons: Explore HDFS Using the Command Line Interface
Setup
Lab

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Explore HDFS Using the Command Line Interface

msg.data: Explore HDFS Using the Command Line Interface

paragraphs.text:
%md
Use the HDFS command line to list the content of the HDFS root directory using the following command:

```shell
$ hdfs dfs -ls /
```

msg.data:
Use the HDFS command line to list the content of the HDFS root directory using the following command:

$ hdfs dfs -ls /

paragraphs.text:
%md
View the content of the /user directory.

You will see your home directory—training—in the listing.

msg.data:
View the content of the /user directory.

You will see your home directory—training—in the listing.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Relative Paths
In HDFS, relative (non-absolute) paths are considered relative to your home directory. There is no concept of a “current” or “working” directory as there is 
in Linux and similar filesystems.

msg.data:
Relative Paths

In HDFS, relative (non-absolute) paths are considered relative to your home directory. There is no concept of a “current” or “working” directory as there is
in Linux and similar filesystems.

paragraphs.title: 2 - View the content of the /user directory

paragraphs.text:
%md
List the contents of your home directory by running:

```shell
$ hdfs dfs -ls /user/training
```
Note that the directory structure in HDFS is unrelated to the directory structure of the local filesystem on the remote host; they are completely separate namespaces.

msg.data:
List the contents of your home directory by running:

$ hdfs dfs -ls /user/training

Note that the directory structure in HDFS is unrelated to the directory structure of the local filesystem on the remote host; they are completely separate namespaces.

paragraphs.title: 3 - List the content of your home directory

paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a new directory called devsh_loudacre in the HDFS root directory. The new directory will be the top-level directory for the remaining exercises in 
the course.

```shell
$ hdfs dfs -mkdir /devsh_loudacre
```

msg.data:
Create a new directory called devsh_loudacre in the HDFS root directory. The new directory will be the top-level directory for the remaining exercises in
the course.

$ hdfs dfs -mkdir /devsh_loudacre

paragraphs.title: 4 - Create the /devsh_loudacre directory

paragraphs.text:
%md
Insert the activations directory into HDFS:

```shell
$ hdfs dfs -put /home/training/training_materials/devsh/data/activations /devsh_loudacre/
```

This copies the local activations directory and its contents into a remote HDFS directory named /devsh_loudacre/activations.

msg.data:
Insert the activations directory into HDFS:

$ hdfs dfs -put /home/training/training_materials/devsh/data/activations /devsh_loudacre/

This copies the local activations directory and its contents into a remote HDFS directory named /devsh_loudacre/activations.

paragraphs.title: 5 - Insert the activations directory into HDFS
6 - Confirm the upload by listing the contents of the new directory

paragraphs.text:
%md
View some of the data you just copied into HDFS.

```shell
$ hdfs dfs -cat /devsh_loudacre/activations/2014-03.xml | head -n 20
```

This prints the first 20 lines of the article to your terminal. This command is handy for viewing text data in HDFS. An individual file is often very large, 
making it inconvenient to view the entire file in the terminal. For this reason, it is often a good idea to pipe the output of the dfs -cat command into head, 
more, or less. You can also use hdfs dfs -tail to more efficiently view the end of the file, rather than piping the whole content.
Note: You may see a warning: cat: Unable to write to output stream. This is because the cat was only able to pipe the first 20 lines because of the limit 
specified in the head command. You can disregard the warning.

msg.data:
View some of the data you just copied into HDFS.

$ hdfs dfs -cat /devsh_loudacre/activations/2014-03.xml | head -n 20

This prints the first 20 lines of the article to your terminal. This command is handy for viewing text data in HDFS. An individual file is often very large,
making it inconvenient to view the entire file in the terminal. For this reason, it is often a good idea to pipe the output of the dfs -cat command into head,
more, or less. You can also use hdfs dfs -tail to more efficiently view the end of the file, rather than piping the whole content.
Note: You may see a warning: cat: Unable to write to output stream. This is because the cat was only able to pipe the first 20 lines because of the limit
specified in the head command. You can disregard the warning.

paragraphs.title: 7 - View some of the data you just copied into HDFS

paragraphs.text:
%md
Practice downloading from HDFS by downloading the directory you uploaded above.

```shell
$ hdfs dfs -get /devsh_loudacre/activations/ /tmp/devsh_activations
```

msg.data:
Practice downloading from HDFS by downloading the directory you uploaded above.

$ hdfs dfs -get /devsh_loudacre/activations/ /tmp/devsh_activations

paragraphs.title: 8 - Practice downloading from HDFS by downloading the directory you uploaded above
9 - List the content of the directory in which you downloaded

paragraphs.text:
%md
Remove the directory you uploaded earlier.

```shell
$ hdfs dfs -rm -r /devsh_loudacre/activations/
```

msg.data:
Remove the directory you uploaded earlier.

$ hdfs dfs -rm -r /devsh_loudacre/activations/

paragraphs.title: 10 - Remove the directory you uploaded earlier

paragraphs.text:
%md
There are several other operations available with the hdfs dfs command to perform most common filesystem manipulations such as mv, cp, and mkdir. Using the 
hdfs dfs command with no arguments will display the available commands.

```shell
$ hdfs dfs
```

msg.data:
There are several other operations available with the hdfs dfs command to perform most common filesystem manipulations such as mv, cp, and mkdir. Using the
hdfs dfs command with no arguments will display the available commands.

$ hdfs dfs

paragraphs.title: 11 - Optional: Continue exploring the HDFS filesystem by experimenting with some of these commands

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Result
**You have now:** practiced working with HDFS using the command line interface.

---

msg.data:
Result

You have now: practiced working with HDFS using the command line interface.
Solution

%md
Return to Cloudera Manager and explore HDFS using the Web UI
Cloudera Manager > HDFS > File Browser

Return to Cloudera Manager and explore HDFS using the Web UI
Cloudera Manager > HDFS > File Browser

paragraphs.title: 2 - View the hdfs dfs syntax

msg.data:
Usage: hadoop fs [generic options]
	[-appendToFile <localsrc> ... <dst>]
	[-cat [-ignoreCrc] <src> ...]
	[-checksum <src> ...]
	[-chgrp [-R] GROUP PATH...]
	[-chmod [-R] <MODE[,MODE]... | OCTALMODE> PATH...]
	[-chown [-R] [OWNER][:[GROUP]] PATH...]
	[-copyFromLocal [-f] [-p] [-l] [-d] [-t <thread count>] <localsrc> ... <dst>]
	[-copyToLocal [-f] [-p] [-ignoreCrc] [-crc] <src> ... <localdst>]
	[-count [-q] [-h] [-v] [-t [<storage type>]] [-u] [-x] [-e] <path> ...]
	[-cp [-f] [-p | -p[topax]] [-d] <src> ... <dst>]
	[-createSnapshot <snapshotDir> [<snapshotName>]]
	[-deleteSnapshot <snapshotDir> <snapshotName>]
	[-df [-h] [<path> ...]]
	[-du [-s] [-h] [-v] [-x] <path> ...]
	[-expunge [-immediate]]
	[-find <path> ... <expression> ...]
	[-get [-f] [-p] [-ignoreCrc] [-crc] <src> ... <localdst>]
	[-getfacl [-R] <path>]
	[-getfattr [-R] {-n name | -d} [-e en] <path>]
	[-getmerge [-nl] [-skip-empty-file] <src> <localdst>]
	[-head <file>]
	[-help [cmd ...]]
	[-ls [-C] [-d] [-h] [-q] [-R] [-t] [-S] [-r] [-u] [-e] [<path> ...]]
	[-mkdir [-p] <path> ...]
	[-moveFromLocal <localsrc> ... <dst>]
	[-moveToLocal <src> <localdst>]
	[-mv <src> ... <dst>]
	[-put [-f] [-p] [-l] [-d] <localsrc> ... <dst>]
	[-renameSnapshot <snapshotDir> <oldName> <newName>]
	[-rm [-f] [-r|-R] [-skipTrash] [-safely] <src> ...]
	[-rmdir [--ignore-fail-on-non-empty] <dir> ...]
	[-setfacl [-R] [{-b|-k} {-m|-x <acl_spec>} <path>]|[--set <acl_spec> <path>]]
	[-setfattr {-n name [-v value] | -x name} <path>]
	[-setrep [-R] [-w] <rep> <path> ...]
	[-stat [format] <path> ...]
	[-tail [-f] [-s <sleep interval>] <file>]
	[-test -[defsz] <path>]
	[-text [-ignoreCrc] <src> ...]
	[-touch [-a] [-m] [-t TIMESTAMP ] [-c] <path> ...]
	[-touchz <path> ...]
	[-truncate [-w] <length> <path> ...]
	[-usage [cmd ...]]

Generic options supported are:
-conf <configuration file>        specify an application configuration file
-D <property=value>               define a value for a given property
-fs <file:///|hdfs://namenode:port> specify default filesystem URL to use, overrides 'fs.defaultFS' property from configurations.
-jt <local|resourcemanager:port>  specify a ResourceManager
-files <file1,...>                specify a comma-separated list of files to be copied to the map reduce cluster
-libjars <jar1,...>               specify a comma-separated list of jar files to be included in the classpath
-archives <archive1,...>          specify a comma-separated list of archives to be unarchived on the compute machines

The general command line syntax is:
command [genericOptions] [commandOptions]
ExitValue: 255

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### The hdfs dfs Options are "Linix Like"
Learn: hdfs is the shell, dfs is the command, and -ls is the option.

HDFS is written in Java. These are not Linux commands, they are Java methods. The HDFS developers intentionally intended the dfs options to be "Linux like". 
You should have the expectations that commands will behave "Linux like", but there are differences.

msg.data:
The hdfs dfs Options are “Linix Like”

Learn: hdfs is the shell, dfs is the command, and -ls is the option.

HDFS is written in Java. These are not Linux commands, they are Java methods. The HDFS developers intentionally intended the dfs options to be “Linux like”.
You should have the expectations that commands will behave “Linux like”, but there are differences.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### HDFS Uses Only Absolute Paths
HDFS actually does not have a concept of directories. All file names are absolute paths. 

#### Working Directory Variable 
There is a HDFS variable setting set to a user's working directory, i.e. /user/training. This variable is called anytime a path begins with a directory name. 
This is intended to allow for shorthand reference to the working directory. Compare the difference between the two -ls commands.

msg.data:
HDFS Uses Only Absolute Paths

HDFS actually does not have a concept of directories. All file names are absolute paths.

Working Directory Variable

There is a HDFS variable setting set to a user's working directory, i.e. /user/training. This variable is called anytime a path begins with a directory name.
This is intended to allow for shorthand reference to the working directory. Compare the difference between the two -ls commands.

paragraphs.title: 6 - Move a directory or file
paragraphs.text:
%sh

hdfs dfs -mv book library
hdfs dfs -ls library

msg.data: mv: `book': No such file or directory

paragraphs.title: 7 - Copy a directory or file
paragraphs.text:
%sh

hdfs dfs -cp library bookstore
hdfs dfs -ls -R

paragraphs.title: 9 - Load the activations directory into HDFS

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### HDFS -put and -get Options
HDFS uses -put to push data from the local file system into HDFS. HDFS users -get to pull data from HDFS back to the local file system.

msg.data:
HDFS -put and -get Options

HDFS uses -put to push data from the local file system into HDFS. HDFS users -get to pull data from HDFS back to the local file system.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### No Shell in HDFS
There is no shell in HDFS. This means there can be no executable inside of HDFS. You cannot run a shell command. 
#### Linux CLI Still Works
But the HDFS shell and HDFS command are executed as a Linux CLI. This means shell expansion, wildcards, pipes, redirects, and variables are 
still available.

msg.data:
No Shell in HDFS

There is no shell in HDFS. This means there can be no executable inside of HDFS. You cannot run a shell command.

Linux CLI Still Works

But the HDFS shell and HDFS command are executed as a Linux CLI. This means shell expansion, wildcards, pipes, redirects, and variables are
still available.

paragraphs.title: 11 - View some of the data you just copied into HDFS

msg.data: cat: `/devsh_loudacre/activations/2014-03.xml': No such file or directory

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### HDFS commands are independent of the terminal
The -cat command will display all of the content of a file, whether this is 2 Gb or 2 Tb. A better practice is to use -head and -tail.

The HDFS client creates the command and submits this to the Hadoop cluster. Once received the job will run independant of the terminal. Exiting a terminal 
will not kill the HDFS command.

msg.data:
HDFS commands are independent of the terminal

The -cat command will display all of the content of a file, whether this is 2 Gb or 2 Tb. A better practice is to use -head and -tail.

The HDFS client creates the command and submits this to the Hadoop cluster. Once received the job will run independant of the terminal. Exiting a terminal
will not kill the HDFS command.

paragraphs.title: 14 - Delete the HDFS directory you uploaded earlier

msg.data: 21/02/01 22:46:00 INFO fs.TrashPolicyDefault: Moved: 'hdfs://localhost.localdomain:8020/devsh_loudacre/activations' to trash at: hdfs://localhost.localdomain:8020/user/zeppelin/.Trash/Current/devsh_loudacre/activations

paragraphs.title: 15 - Recover the deleted data

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Retrieving Deleted Data
HDFS created a .Trash folder for the zeppelin user and moved the deleted contents into .Trash. This content may be moved back. 
~~~
hdfs dfs -cp /user/zeppelin/.Trash/Current/devsh_loudacre/activations /devsh_loudacre/
~~~
#### .Trash
Similar to Macs and PCs there is a .Trash feature. The difference is the data loaded into .Trash has a time to live, by default this is six hours. At the end 
of this period the data will be automatically deleted from the .Trash directory.

msg.data:
Retrieving Deleted Data

HDFS created a .Trash folder for the zeppelin user and moved the deleted contents into .Trash. This content may be moved back.

hdfs dfs -cp /user/zeppelin/.Trash/Current/devsh_loudacre/activations /devsh_loudacre/

.Trash

Similar to Macs and PCs there is a .Trash feature. The difference is the data loaded into .Trash has a time to live, by default this is six hours. At the end
of this period the data will be automatically deleted from the .Trash directory.

paragraphs.title: 16 - Permanent delete data

msg.data: Deleted book

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Permentantly Deleting Data
To permentantly delete data use the -skipTrash option.
~~~
hdfs dfs -rm -r -skipTrash /devsh_loudacre/activations/
~~~

msg.data:
Permentantly Deleting Data

To permentantly delete data use the -skipTrash option.

hdfs dfs -rm -r -skipTrash /devsh_loudacre/activations/

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### HDFS Data Blocks are Immutable
The "File exists" error message will interput your scripts. HDFS data blocks are immutable and cannot be overwritten. It is good practice to always check 
for the existance of directories and data in HDFS before creating new directories or loading data.

msg.data:
HDFS Data Blocks are Immutable

The “File exists” error message will interput your scripts. HDFS data blocks are immutable and cannot be overwritten. It is good practice to always check
for the existance of directories and data in HDFS before creating new directories or loading data.

paragraphs.title: 18 - Recommended practice to delete before put

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Delete Before Put
HDFS data blocks are immutable. They can not be overwritten! The recommended practice is to delete the file, even if it does not exist, before copying in 
data into HDFS. This practice will reduce failures in loading data.

msg.data:
Delete Before Put

HDFS data blocks are immutable. They can not be overwritten! The recommended practice is to delete the file, even if it does not exist, before copying in
data into HDFS. This practice will reduce failures in loading data.

paragraphs.title: 19 - Purge hdfs .Trash

msg.data:
21/02/01 23:49:19 INFO fs.TrashPolicyDefault: TrashPolicyDefault#deleteCheckpoint for trashRoot: hdfs://localhost.localdomain:8020/user/zeppelin/.Trash
21/02/01 23:49:19 INFO fs.TrashPolicyDefault: TrashPolicyDefault#deleteCheckpoint for trashRoot: hdfs://localhost.localdomain:8020/user/zeppelin/.Trash
21/02/01 23:49:19 INFO fs.TrashPolicyDefault: Deleted trash checkpoint: /user/zeppelin/.Trash/210201230000
21/02/01 23:49:19 INFO fs.TrashPolicyDefault: TrashPolicyDefault#createCheckpoint for trashRoot: hdfs://localhost.localdomain:8020/user/zeppelin/.Trash
Tear down

paragraphs.title: Delete HDFS directory
paragraphs.text:
%sh

hdfs dfs -rm -r -skipTrash /devsh_loudacre
hdfs dfs -rm -r -skipTrash book library

msg.data:
Deleted /devsh_loudacre
rm: `book': No such file or directory
Deleted library
Deleted william
Deleted dailey
ExitValue: 1

paragraphs.title: Delete the tmp directory
Additional resources
paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Cloudera Tutorials](http://cloudera.com/tutorials.html) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Cloudera Community](https://community.cloudera.com) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Apache Spark Documentation](https://spark.apache.org/documentation.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Apache Zeppelin Project Home Page](https://zeppelin.apache.org) - official Zeppelin web site.

msg.data:
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

  1. Cloudera Tutorials are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
  2. Cloudera Community is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
  3. Apache Spark Documentation - official Spark documentation.
  4. Apache Zeppelin Project Home Page - official Zeppelin web site.
